author: Aakanksha Aggarwal
description:
Inspired by Zach Lieberman's article about his practice of daily sketching.

This particular sketch was interesting because I started out by trying to incorporate the double random function by Ira Greenberg. (https://p5js.org/examples/math-double-random.html) After a few tries, I started working towards a specific outcome, which was to create a gradient. I like this process of co-creation, of the outcome informing the process. 
One thing that I want to work on is organizing the code. This sketch, for instance, has a very messy code.

author: Julian H. Lange
description: W13S03: Iko Iko ~ translated the notes (which I found [here](https://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0145670)) into a p5 sound sketch, saved the piece as a wav file, then moved over to Photoshop to combine the wav file with a video I took from a trip to New Orleans in 2016. Compare the synthesized version above with the (much better) original version below. [Here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iko_Iko) is the story that the lyrics tell. For those who have not yet been to New Orleans, the street music is outstanding! Hear the sketch on [Cloud9](https://preview.c9users.io/julianhlange/comp-form/sketches/week13/sketch03/index.html?_c9_id=livepreview0&_c9_host=https://ide.c9.io).

description:
My attempt at making a deer that doesn't quite look like one. I started using different stroke colors to debug and then liked the way it looked so kept it in the final.

As I was making curves I realized that we can control the smoothness by increasing the number of steps and reducing the distance traveled each time. Super basic but was interesting to see it play out.

Added the eye later in Photoshop.

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W7 Turtles: "[Friendly Neighbourhood Spidey](https://mariodcunha.github.io/turtle-spidey/)"

[Interact with the Spidey here, but don't scare it!](https://mariodcunha.github.io/turtle-spidey/)

Animal Challenge: I started off to draw a dragon, and then an actual simple turtle, and then just settled for a spider. 

I found the intricacies in the dragon and turtle too taxing and time-consuming and get it in place, and so I made this bug, which is something I might use on websites, like animated cursors, icons, etc.

Finally, I figured out how to move the spider through the push/pop states. I was 'bitten' by inspiration from Leah's fly! So beautiful!
I intend to make the web and finer textures and creepy furry stuff on this spider, but this itself took me a ton of time.

[Code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/tree/master/turtle-spidey)

author: Carla Molins
description:
I worked on the workflow between Cinema 4d and illustrator.

I created 3D geometric models using Cinema 4D. I applied a texture that looks like a drawing to export it. Later on, I imported the file to illustrator to keep editing it. 

The shapes are quite simple, but as you can see there some coming from some other shapes but with a different amount of rows ( sphere vs. spherical zone  or cone vs conical frustum).

Right now, working on exporting different shapes, to compose a nice poster. I'll post it tomorrow.

author: Carla Molins
description:
Challenge 2:  Load an image and process its pixels. Show the result.

This is my personal exploration about pixel processing with a given image through the slit-scan technique. In this case, this is a faux slit-scan because it's from still image and I'm just using noise to fake de movement. I really like the first image, the others seem more random distortions to me.

However, I had some issues because of the pre-processing, it was running so slow...

I decided to continue my exploration on Anni Albers' artworks.

This time I decided to work with two of her pieces in order to recreate them with a randomised pattern created with a proper grid, shapes and colours.

First piece done with processing.
Second with P5, using the same base than the processing code.

Lastly, for this series I had to apply some basic geometry, because the accuracy of the shapes matter when you try to recognise the piece.

author: Aakanksha Aggarwal
description:
I realized if we input noise into the fill function, we can create super cool gradients. The function receives the x and the y coordinates as arguments and by using a variety of operators on them, different combinations can be made. These are some variations I made by modifying the line of code below! 

//fill(noise(x * y) * 200, noise(x / y) * 150, noise(x - y) * 200);

[Interact](https://mariodcunha.github.io/7wondergenerator/) and [Code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/tree/master/7wondergenerator)

By clicking the info bubbles, you can surf through the NEW wonders when the heading shows 'new' and the OLD wonders, when it shows OLD. To switch between NEW and OLD worlds, click the respective words in the heading. 

You will experience the font, sound, theme and image matching with the random generation. No Wonder is immediately chosen next from the random 7 set but may occur alternately. 

Before the lady starts speaking, you can also say "CHANGE OLD" or "CHANGE NEW" to surf the wonders with voice.

Library: jQuery

Exploration: Nature is Design. Square tiles force us to imagine patterns over them, whereas non-square tiles create patterns themselves. Ex: The leaves appear rotating around a closed center but later in the pattern, they also appear revolving around an open center. Honeybees and honeycombs have always inspired me about the tiny purposes and decisions of design in nature.

author: Max Xia
description:
#CaseStudy
[Read More](http://longzexia.net/case-study/)
My project is about creating a VR space that people can enter and experience being surrounded by a group of abstract asteroids-like objects. The tool I used is the particle system in Unity 3D. However, the default settings could not produce the effects I wanted, so I read the document and control the particles by scripts. During the coding process, I did some motion design adapted from motions of a group of fish to make the particles more interesting. I was also inspired by Yayoi Kusama’s Infinity Room and a video installation art designed by Sonia Falcone. As a result, there are some reflective stripes floating in the space to create an immersive experience for viewers.

author: Rik Ghosh
description: Four oscillators generating two "notes" forming roughly a major third. Two of the oscillators are set to the frequency of C4 and E4, but the other two are slightly off—the net result is a 3 vs. 4 beat pattern generated without any explicit rhythm changes.  The frequencies of the lower two oscillators generate 4 beats per second, and the frequencies of the upper two generate 3 beats per second, which, mathematically,  does not fit together because they have no common divisor.

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W2 Random: 'Annie Alber'.

[Interact](https://mariodcunha.github.io/random-tiles/) and [Code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/tree/master/random-tiles)

This is my attempt at giving my take on Annie Alber's work, combining with tiles from the previous week, and exploring the depth of one changing factor. Here, each tile is a square with a randomly rotating triangle. A new color palette is generated with a mouse-click. The Gap between tiles can be increased by pressing SPACE and decreased by pressing B. This generated another family of patterns.

This came out after I tried a lot with regular square tiles and generating different palettes.

Library: p5.js

You may try interacting with it on [GitHub](https://mariodcunha.github.io/random-tiles/)

author: Leah Willemin
description:
Using recordings of myself walking down steps, and looping them to create rhythms. 

I've enjoyed playing with recorded audio in this sketch, and finding successful combinations. Each of these includes some randomized parameters for variation. In setting the range for random, I really noticed the way wide variation generates mostly samey, mediocre things--but sometimes a really unusual and interesting result. A smaller range of variation may yield more consistently decent results, but not find the interesting outliers.

author: Aakanksha Aggarwal
description:
I am intrigued by generating movement that looks organic. I wanted to create the ripples in waters/ waves. This somehow looks like sand on a beach to me. Will keep working on getting my waves right. 

I was struggling with the problems of skipped frames and was manually renaming them so as to not get blank frames while I was stitching it together in Photoshop. That's when it struck me that the frames were being skipped because it was taking longer to render them than the frame rate allowed. Reduced the frame rate to 1, and it worked just fine! It was awesome to see what we were talking about in class play out!

author: Patricia Robinson
description: For my case study I chose to make sketchbook challenges to combat workaholism. Small games encourage disconnecting from harmful habits. Here's an example:  1. Look at your watch. Walk in any direction for 10 minutes. Set an alarm if you need to. Stop, exactly when the time is up. Take note of how you feel. What do you see? Can you describe the colors in the sky? What is to your left? What is to your right? Can you hear anything? Are there people talking? Cars buzzing around? Is there construction?

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W2 Random: "Skyline"

[Interact](https://mariodcunha.github.io/random-skyline/) and [Code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/tree/master/random-skyline)

This is inspired by the past week pictures of the New York skyline at the UN. Also inspired by Justin's skyline dice-roll-charts. 

Each building is generated by creating a random tile with sub-titles as windows and this pattern is pulled to a random height, and then another building is created and so on. The height, floor size, window size, roof existing, and black tint of the building, window, and sky are generated in a calculated random fashion.

Note: Pressing any key will toggle the window lights inside the building to random or constant for any building. The mouse click always repaints the picture.

Check it out [here](https://mariodcunha.github.io/random-skyline/).

Library: p5.js

author: Carla Molins
description:
This is my exploration on pixels composition and manipulation with P5.

Pixels[] allows me to change each pixel individually through RGBA channels.

I created a RGBA colour swatch maker using 4 parameters through a for loop.

In addition I started to play around with different combination for modifying the channels achieving an interesting gradient.

Needs more exploration to create more interesting visual results.

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W4 Noise: "[RandomNoise](https://mariodcunha.github.io/jstips/RandomNoise.html)"

"RandomNoise" is a quick function framework which I came up with to just understand and toggle between random(), noise() and using both together. I created this to help myself understand noise in comparison with random() and translate it visually.

Inspired by brainstorming with Aakanksha, while we decoded what noise() is /does.

You can read more [here](https://mariodcunha.github.io/jstips/RandomNoise.html), and check the [code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/blob/master/jstips/RandomNoise.js). Hope this will help you get more control out of noise().

author: Carla Molins
description:
*CASE STUDY*

This case study shapes a personal exploration
about the connection between Computational
Generated Images (P5.js) and Haptic
Interfaces (Arduino + capacitive sensing)
with one core shared element, sound.

Therefore, the goal is to create a physical
musical interface that creates both sounds
and computer-generated visuals.

Tap box 2.0 is a haptic box system that
translates a tactile musical interaction into
a visual pattern resultant of the sequence
generated.

This project takes places within a broader
scope exploring physicality and materiality
of data. In this case, the data provides from
the different sounds triggered by capacitive
sensors. The data represented corresponds
to the number of times each note has been
played.

More information, and process, here:
https://issuu.com/krly240/docs/case_study_paper

And OCR-A is the digital typeface designed based on this technology.

I used the OCR-A font in my first bumper.

author: Earl NIE
description:
[Case Study]
---
[WEBSITE](http://luqinie.com/project/time-space-and-universe)  [DEMO](https://sssirius.github.io/niel641_ComFormCode_18/case/index.html)
---
I try to reshape the sense of time and space in the universe on a two-dimensional media. 
---
Twisted spatial sensations are created by the angle differences between the star-tracks, while the depth of field and the light effect are created by brightness and saturation.

The main process is divided into:
1. Track Drawing.
Draw the basic track and set the track characteristics (color, the angle of each section, misalignment of the same-grade track)
2. The constellation Setting.
Set the location, size, shape, and detail of the distribution of the constellation (halo, own internal orbit)
3. Randomness.
On the basis of the previous work, keep adding more variables, like the number of tracks,  rotation angle for an individual track, displacement, distance between each track, etc.,
---
detailed info will update later

author: Aakanksha Aggarwal
description:
A poem about life. 
For machine use only. 

I am intrigued by how in a world where machines communicate with machines so extensively, there is always an attempt to translate what they are saying to make it understandable to the human. Machines are made to work for us- to be used for purposes we deem useful. What if we worked for machines? What would poetry be like? Would it still exist?

Inspired by a lovely project that Li is doing, where she is looking at coding languages as an extension of other spoken and written languages.

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W5 Strategy: "[Gameplay: Ball and Obstacles](https://mariodcunha.github.io/ball-obstacle/)"

[Play here](https://mariodcunha.github.io/ball-obstacle/)

This is a two-player game I made along with my studio partner, Jungu Guo, in the two-week "play" project exploration. This started off with an exploration of 'play' but of course shaped up to be a simple game.

Rules: Connect two mouse (mice) to your computer. Each player controls one mouse, and the goal is to pull the ball to your side. Obstacles will kill the ball gradually, killing both.

Objective: Players need to co-operate to avoid killing the ball for both of them so that at least one of them reaches their corner to win, else both lose/draw/tie.

Hope you like the experience.

[Code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/tree/master/ball-obstacle)

description:
Tried modifying the in-class example to generate different sounds, which I then went on to layer in Adobe Premiere Pro. One problem that I ran into was that the way the tone sounded varied from the browser to the software to the finished compressed file. Also, tones that sounded alright on the browser, were almost tearing (I don't know the technical term for that- but it is an unpleasant, high pitched sound).

While editing the files in Premiere Pro- I started playing with clipping the sounds and tried to make sound patterns- guided by the graphical interface.

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W14 Microgames: 'Gritty Gravity'

This was created during the Play week from Major Studio. I really want to post this here because this game particularly tries to have co-operation and competition at the same time.

This does seem like a single player game, but its not. It's a multi-player game vying for single control of the white ball. This is inspired from tug of war, air hockey.

This was also play-tested during PlayTech April 2018, with some amazing feedback and results.

Prototyping with JS
Made with UNITY
Team Mate: Jungu Guo

description:
One last frog, with some more image processing.

This is sort of a silly exercise, but it was a fun proof of concept: a reduction woodcut "printed" digitally. I like being able to layer and alter the image, and would explore this idea further with a more complex image and more interesting image processing. Originally, I was thinking of coding a simple black and white animation, and then re-processing it as a map for image processing (like the grass example). The woodcut was another take on this idea, but I'd like to do the original, as well, in order to make things move more--the frog doesn't really have motion.

author: Carla Molins
description:
Today I decided to leave my computer aside and play as a computer myself. I grabbed a physical dictionary as my main text source.

1. I defined a basic grammar structure
2.  Randomly pick up a page. (Start reading upper-left side)
3. Look for the first adjective. Write it down.
4. Repeat 2 and look for a noun. Write it down.
5. Repeat 2 and look for a verb. Write it down.
6. Repeat 2 and look for an adverb or noun whichever you find first. Write it down.
7. Decide and write down an article for the sentence.
8. Draw a line under the sentence.
9. Start from 2 again.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
I thought I'd make up a mini challenge and make a sketch that only calls `random()` from one place. This sketch generates and draws a [Binary Space Partition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_space_partitioning). It starts with a rectangle, divides it in half, divides those in half, and so on. The rectangles might be divided horizontally or vertically; that is where the `random()` comes in. 


[Source](https://jsbin.com/lifopimaxo/edit?js,output)

author: Sue / Xu Han
description:
[Week9.2] Excited to do something on my domain interest about language. This is an experimental hieroglyphic language system based on English words. 

A circle divided by 26 lines. Each line represented an alphabet. Started from A,  B rotated clockwise 13.85 degrees (360/26); C rotated 13.85 degrees to B. And so on. Each alphabet has a unique direction. Then in code, each time keypressed a key, drew the degrees that I set.

Linear English words end up with some hieroglyphic line graphic. Is it possible to understand a language by using our graphic thinkings?

These graphics really like some constellation graphics right?

description:
【Case Study】
Trigonometry is one of the important and fundamental topics in the field of computer graphics. Trigonometry for me is the study of relationship and the wonder of it lies in the potential infinity and similarity insides.

Starting from introducing basic trigonometry functions, my case study explores the application of trigonometry in graphics programming and especially in digital painting using Processing as the platform. There are 3 stages of work following a procedural process. Serving as a foundation, stage 1 reveals characteristics of trigonometry by drawing curves and applies it to create natural-looking motion. The next stage focuses especially on cyclical motion and shows trigonometry’s potential in generating patterns based on endless repetition. And ultimately, the last stage experiments with digital painting ideas by creating a dynamic brush using trigonometry and show the modified result with an example.

Below are some of my result sketches. A website documentation coming soon...

[Written Document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1cNtRoSkdEIJIQSTxwlOJh4aWLLfuOXV9_ksibQY2uak/edit?usp=sharing)

[Website Document](https://www.wuyandesign.com/comp-form-case-study) (recommended, with video documentation)

author: Patricia Robinson
description: Something about nature is really therapeutic. Took a walk this morning. Realized a lot of what I love about computers is simulating natural systems to create interesting mixed realized. Not really taking about AR/VR but just a different spin on everyday things like watching milk spill into coffee or the humming of cars on the street. Used noise in p5 to simulate water. Thinking about mixing mediums next. Maybe graphic design? Maybe photography? Maybe print? Maybe audio?

author: Leah Willemin
description:
[CASE STUDY] I designed parametric flat-pack jewelry for laser or waterjet cutting. I used paper.js  to create the patterns. User input includes drawing shapes as well as setting parameters like width. I laser cut some of the results, testing different paper and plastic options. My goal would be to cut these out of powder-coated aluminum sheet with a waterjet cutter, for finished jewelry pieces.

http://leahwillemin.com/Parametric-Jewelry

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W13 3D: Hoverglobe

Still working on this. TinkerCAD is far more amazing that just being a basic tool. Esp for a beginner! I mean I don't even need to print these. The TinkerCAD screen renditions are so amazing, and light!

Feels great to feel, touch and rotate your object than generate it with code. 

What I'm really liking here is the ease to get those bevels at every opening, that I struggled with code, so gave up. Also, notice the shadows below! Illuminating!

author: Mario Dcunha
description:
W4 Noise: "[RandomNoise - Bubbles](https://mariodcunha.github.io/RandomNoise-bubbles/)".

I am learning the use of noise, by comparing it with random. Therefore, I made a system using parameters, called "RandomNoise" where I can toggle between Noise, Random, and Noise-with-Random. 

This is helping me understand the functions, and also relate to it visually and by interaction.

The Bubbles are inspired by Daniel Shiffman's Particle System.

[Code](https://github.com/mariodcunha/mariodcunha.github.io/tree/master/RandomNoise-bubbles)
